isis.stitle: 10 SPEED TRANSMISSIONS FULLER RT-610 SERIES - AIR SYSTEM - TROUBLESHOOTING

svcprocinfo.para: If the transmission fails to make a range shift or shifts too slow, the fault may be in the air system or actuating parts in the shifter housing. To check the air system and pinpoint the trouble area, the following procedures are recommended, using the check points indicated by letters in Figure 2.
Checks are to be made with the vehicle engine off, but with normal vehicle air pressure.

svcsubproc.title: Incorrect Hook-Up
svcsubproc.para: With normal vehicle air pressure and gear shift lever in the neutral position, move the control button up and down, from one range to another.

step1.para: If lines are crossed between the control valve and the air valve on the transmission, there will be a steady flow of air from the bottom exhaust in the control valve with button in the up position.

If lines are crossed between the air valve on the transmission and the air or shift cylinder, the transmission gearing will not correspond with the button position. Low range, down position of button, will result in high range gear engagement in the transmission and vice versa.

svcsubproc.title: Air Leaks
svcsubproc.para: With normal vehicle air pressure and gear shift lever in the neutral position, coat all air lines and fittings with soapy water and check for leaks, moving control button to both positions.

step1.para: If there is a steady leak out the exhaust of the control valve, there are defective parts or O-rings in the control valve.
If there is a steady leak out the breather on the air valve: there is a defective O-ring in the air valve, or there is a leak past the O-rings on the shift cylinder piston.
If transmission fails to shift into low range or is slow to make the shift and the transmission case is pressurized, refer to Check Point E in Figure 3.
Tighten all loose connections and replace defective parts or O-rings.

svcsubproc.title: Check Point A, Air Regulator
svcsubproc.para: With normal line pressure and gear shift lever in neutral, check the exhaust port of the air regulator. There should be no leak from this port.
Cut off the vehicle air pressure and install an air gauge in the line at the output port of the air regulator. Bring vehicle air pressure to normal. Regulated pressure should be 57.5 to 62.5.

Only as a last resort should an adjustment be made with the screw in the bottom of the regulator. This adjustment has been set for correct operating limits. Any deviation from these limits, especially on regulators which have been in operation for some time, will in most cases be caused by dirt or worn parts. Adjustment of the screw will give only a temporary remedy.

step1.para: Turning screw in (clockwise) raises air pressure.
Turning screw out lowers air pressure.

svcsubproc.para: Air regulator is not serviceable and should be replaced if defective.

svcsubproc.title: Check Point B
svcsubproc.para: With normal vehicle air pressure and gear shift lever in the neutral position, pull the control button up to high range and disconnect the 1/8 inch nylon air line from the out port of the control valve at the air valve.

step1.para: When the control button is pushed down, a steady blast of air will flow from the disconnected line. Air will shut off when the button is pulled up. This indicates that the control valve is operating correctly. Reconnect the air line.
If the control valve does not operate correctly, check for restrictions and leaks; leaks indicate bad O-rings.

svcsubproc.title: Check Point C
svcsubproc.para: With normal vehicle air pressure and gear shift lever in the neutral position, push the control button down to the low range position and disconnect the high range air line, either at the fitting on the shift cylinder or at the side port of the air valve.

step1.para: Pull control button up. There should be a steady flow of air from the high range port. Push button down to shut off air.

Make sure the vehicle engine is off and move the gear shift lever to a gear position. Pull the button up; there should be no air at the high range port. Move the gear shift lever to neutral; there should now be a steady flow of air from the high range port. Push the button down to shut off the air and reconnect the high range air line.
If the air system operates incorrectly, this indicates that the air valve is defective, or that the actuating parts in the shifter housing are jammed or defective.

svcsubproc.title: Check Point D
svcsubproc.para: With normal vehicle air pressure and gear shift lever in the neutral position, pull the control button up to high range and disconnect the low range air line, either at the fitting on the shift cylinder or at the side port of the air valve.

step1.para: Repeat the procedures under Check Point C, reversing the position of the control button to check the low range operation.

svcsubproc.title: Check Point E
svcsubproc.para: If any of the seals in the range shift cylinder are defective, the range shift will be affected. The degree of lost air will govern the degree of failure, from slow shift to complete failure.

step1.para: Leak at seal A or B results in failure to shift into either low or high range; steady leak out the air valve breather in both ranges.
Leak at seal C results in failure to shift into low range; pressurizing of the transmission.
